Yesterday, Manitoba set a single-day record of new COVID-19 cases, with Dr. Brent Rusen hinting at more restrictions to flatten the curve. And as Manitoba looks into an uncertain few next few weeks, we're turning now to one of our province's former Chief Public Health Officers for his insights into the virus and how to handle it. Joining me now is Dr. Joel Kettner, now an associate professor at the University of Manitoba's College of Medicine. Good morning to you, Dr. Kettner. Good morning. So as mentioned, you served as Manitoba's Chief Medical Officer of Health from 1999 to 2012. During your tenure, you dealt with concerns about viral outbreaks, but really not on this level. That's true. In fact, you could say we had a pandemic every year with influenza. It meets the criteria for a pandemic. But right now, we're using this term in quite a different way. And even the pandemic of 2009, H1N1 influenza, or other similar kinds of challenges that got our attention like SARS and at one point Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, which are both coronaviruses, there's never been really a response to a respiratory virus like we're seeing now around the world and in Manitoba. I mean, sometimes we talk about the virus causing all of these problems, but we have to also think of the response to the virus, which is causing quite a bit of issues too. So I just want to put in a couple of quick caveats. I'm not criticizing government decisions or our public health leaders. They have a lot more information about what's going on than I do. So I have to be respectful and humble about that. And I'm also not recommending that people should reject or not follow the directives or advice. But I do have questions about the policies and the attempts that are being used, not just in Manitoba but elsewhere, to try to interrupt the spread of this virus or control its impacts. So what are some of your questions and concerns, Dr. Kettner? Obviously, we've had restrictions. We've had lockdowns in the past and we could be facing more restrictions going forward. So what are kind of your main concerns? Well, in public health, we have to look at the big picture. And we have to think about not just one disease, but all diseases and injuries and causes of morbidity and mortality. And we have to also think about the impacts of our interventions, the side effects. We call them in medicine, but the harms of interventions. And I think we're learning more about what those harms are and how they're maybe unfairly distributed and affecting people differently based on single parents, people working for hourly wages, small enterprises which are closing, big effect on the economy and our deficit of government, impacts on education. I mean, we're learning more and more about what those harmful impacts are. So what's the benefit? Well, the benefit is, as we know, to try to flatten the curve. In other words, to try to prevent our hospitals being overrun with cases and to try to reduce the mortality, especially premature mortality. How much benefit do these lockdowns and restrictions have? No doubt they have some impact. But we have to put this in perspective. So here's a few numbers which I think your listeners might find interesting and important. 4,500 cases in Manitoba, that represents less than 0.3% of our population. One in 300 people so far have had a positive test result. 58 deaths, that's one per 25,000 Manitobans. One in 25,000 Manitobans have died. That's less than 1% of all deaths. In other words, less than 1% of all causes of death. ICU admissions, 15, that's about 20% of our ICU beds. In a typical flu season, the majority of ICU beds are taken up by people with a variety of viral and bacterial causes of acute lung injury or pneumonia. And we so far from estimates, from descriptions of our capacity for ventilators, we're using up less than 1% of our ventilator capacity. So Dr. Kettner, what are you... I want to add one more point. Hospitalizations, 83 hospitalizations, that's less than 3% of all our beds. So we just have to put into perspective the impact that this disease is having. Our moon. A strange thing, don't you think? Have you ever gazed upon a full moon and wondered, wondered how it got there, what strange forces could have possibly built it? There are many moons within our solar system, yet few are as strange as ours. No others are known to ring like a bell when struck. No others possess such luminosity as our moon. In the 1970s, Michael Vassan and Alexander Shashurbakov of what was then the Soviet Academy of Sciences created a thesis that the moon is actually the remnants of a very ancient spaceship created by, as yet, unknown civilization. The article was entitled Is the Moon the Creation of Alien Intelligence and was published in Sputnik, the Soviet equivalent of Reader's Digest. The suggestion of a hollow moon first appeared in science fiction when H. G. Wells wrote about a hollow moon in his 1901 book The First Men in the Moon. Michael Vassan and Alexander Shashurbakov's hypothesis is based on the fact that large lunar craters, generally assumed to be formed from massive meteor impacts, are generally too shallow for scars made upon an organic body, and can have flat or even convex bottoms. They propose that small meteors are making cup-shaped depressions in the rocky surface of the moon, while the larger meteors are drilling through a rocky upper layer, hitting an armored hull underneath. Does George Lucas know something we don't? It seems he couldn't resist adding just one crater. The authors referenced earlier speculations by astrophysicist Iosif Shiklovsky, who suggested that the Martian moon Phobos was an artificial satellite and hollow. Interestingly, Phobos has been claimed to appear to be hollow by numerous astronomers, who have stated that it appears to have an opening on one side, making it, in a sense, similar in shape to an empty shell. Phobos' orbit is also a complete mystery. Many who have researched it claimed that it should have crashed into the surface of Mars many moons ago. Between 1972 and 1977, seismometers installed on our moon by the Apollo missions recorded strange moonquakes. The moon was described to have been ringing like a bell during some of those The support of evidence was then brought to popular attention in March 1970, in an article in popular science. When Apollo 12 deliberately crashed the ascent stage of its lunar module into the moon's surface, it was claimed that the moon rang like a bell for an hour, leading to arguments that it must be hollow. Several YouTubers, most notably Crow777, have supposedly recorded what is now known as lunar waves, if confirmed to exist. This may prove there is some form of functioning shield or scanning system being seen working on its surface. The fact that the moon is less dense than the earth is also strong supportive evidence that it is indeed hollow.

The more I argued with them, the better I came to know they're dialectic. First they counted on the stupidity of their adversary, and then, when there was no other way out, they themselves simply played stupid. If all this didn't help, they pretended not to understand, or if challenged, they changed the subject in a hurry, quoted platitudes which, if you accepted them, they immediately related to entirely different matters. And then, if again attacked, gave ground and pretended not to know exactly what you were talking about. Whenever you tried to attack one of these apostles, your hand closed on a jelly-like slime which divided up and poured through your fingers, but in the next moment collected again. But if you really struck one of these fellows so telling the blow that, observed by the audience, he couldn't help but agree, and if you believed that this had taken you at least one step forward, your amazement was great the next day. It had not the slightest recollection of the day before. He rattled off the same old nonsense as though nothing at all had happened, and if indignantly challenged, affected amazement. He couldn't remember a thing, except that he had proved the correctness of his assertions the previous day. Sometimes I stood there, thunderstruck. I didn't know what to be more amazed at, the agility of their tongues, or the virtuosity of their lying. Gradually, I began to hate them.

The black community in America, like many others, has a culture comprised of strong in-group preference. Despite things like this portionally high rate of black on black crime, there still exists a near universal mutual respect shared by black people for being black, even if it's not expressed explicitly. Because of that, racial betrayal is one of the most emotionally charged offenses within the black community, and titles for this offense range from Uncle Tom to Sambo to House Nigga and most commonly, Coon. Now I know a lot of right wing conservatively named blacks will argue that Coon is just a term used to silence blacks for wrong think. Others will probably argue that it's just another cancerous form of identity politics. And sometimes that is true, but not always. And while some people, black and non-black alike, may not recognize the concept of Coon to be legitimate, in the black community it is an established cultural axiom. In this video, I wanted to take a shot at explaining from the perspective of a black person what exactly makes someone guilty of being a Coon. Let's get started. First let's define our terms. Now there's a lot of different definitions for the word Coon. According to Urban Dictionary, a Coon is a black actor or actress who takes roles that stereotypically portrays black people, which I'm not sure is accurate because I find examples like character James Carter from Rush Hour who is the stereotypical black American sidekick to be hilarious. Or the boys of Summer from The Wire who play the role of stereotypical young black American men selling drugs. I love all these characters and to my knowledge they're all equally beloved by a majority of black demographics too. So I'm not sure if it's only Cooning when it's a stereotype that black people don't like or you know whatever. Another definition according to Webster is an insulting or contemptuous term for a black person. Again, while vaguely true, these definitions aren't really what I'm talking about. So since I couldn't find a definition that matches the context of which I'll be referring to the term throughout this video, I wouldn't head and wrote my own. In my opinion I think it's a sufficient definition of the word Coon as it's most commonly used by black people would be this. A black person displaying favoritism to non-black people usually white whilst collectively condemning their own race for not being more culturally identical to the race they favor. The reason I chose this definition is because the nature of Cooning isn't how many describe it. It's not merely acting white nor is it merely black on black criticism. Rather, Cooning is a sociological action, one that requires a conscious intent to subvert or defame black identity. We'll get into some examples of what I would say are reasonable perceived cases of Cooning in just a bit, but first let's talk about what Cooning is not. Oftentimes people misattribute Cooning to mean anything another black person does that they themselves don't like. And when people unreasonably use language it makes the meaning of the term pretty useless and the term Coon has been hella abused in this respect. For example, a black person having a romantic relationship with someone of another race is not inherently Cooning. Is it possible that they're doing so because they have insecurities about their own race, culture, etc. and want to distance themselves from their blackness? Sure. It's also possible that they have no issue with being black and the person accusing them of Cooning are themselves insecure and are projecting their emotions onto an innocent relationship. It's much more likely that you're just salty and bitter because they didn't choose you, but I ain't trying to hurt nobody's feelings. Another example of unreasonable use of the word Coon is the classic you talk white. If you're so stupid as to think that the adoption of proper English means that someone is pandering to whites, bruh. Being literate is not in opposition to black people or black culture. Other examples include claims that you know wearing your jeans weighs high makes you a Coon, straightening or coloring your hair makes you a Coon, not voting for Obama or Democrats makes you a Coon. I could go on and on with how stupid some of this shit can be and I've learned from experience that trying to reason with stupid people is more than often a waste of time so we're gonna leave it at that. While these are some of the dumbest examples of Coon accusations, they still fall under the definition outlined earlier, that being a perception of disloyalty to the black collective. But now let's talk about some other examples of Cooning which even I as a pretty solid individualist can understand being classified as such. Cooning from my experience seems to manifest itself in one of two forms, those being passive and aggressive. Passive Cooning is probably the most common, a good example of this phenomena would be CNN host Don Lemon. Now Don is someone who I'll criticize for a number of things. His mainstream leftist propaganda, his incessant whining about racism or his hilariously mediocre career as a journalist. I would love to spend more time with you. You are an incredible guy, thank you so much. What the hell did you bring me on the show for? I put you on the show to get you on to talk about your series, we talked for a long time. I know but we talked for a long time off the camera. The new show Mike Tyson mysteries airs every Monday night at 10.30 PM. Don Lemon's full of himself. I don't swim. Thank you Mike Tyson. Love bro. I love you too. But none of those things make him a Coon. Instead Don Lemon's Cooning stems from his appeals to improve the black community by whitewashing the culture. You see Don Lemon is his mainstream as mainstream blacks come. He's made a career out of assimilating into the milieu of white elites. And he's fared quite well as a result. Not only Lemon, but plenty of other black personalities. Charles Barkley, Ben Carson, Stacey Dash, Raven Simone, etc. The one thing all these guys have in common is an expressed favor of Eurocentric or mainstream American culture over black American culture. But I call it passive Cooning because the favor of white culture expressed by these individuals is, well, passive. And it isn't followed up with an explicit disparagement of black people or black culture, which is usually a tactic of aggressive Cooning. Unlike passive Cooning, aggressive Cooning is an act where a black person consciously divorces themselves from black culture. Again, in conjunction with the typical adoption of white American culture. A prime example of what could be perceived as aggressive Cooning would be Tree of Logic. Let me preface this by making clear that this isn't me taking shots and calling Tree of Coon. To my knowledge, we were cool until I randomly discovered she blocked me on Twitter. But that's besides the point. I'm only using Tree as a strategic illustration. It's not personal. So first, let me explain a little bit of background. Tree of Logic is a YouTuber whose channel somewhat overlaps with mine in that we're both black right wing YouTubers. Which is basically a niche category because there are so few of us. Anyway, myself and Tree both at one point had some pretty vocal alliances with the alt-right. As of late, I noticed we've both slowly begun to separate ourselves from the movement. Now I did so gradually in favor more so of promoting black capitalism and free association type stuff. Tree, however, seemed to do so at the blink of an eye after she got BTFO by Mike Enoch on the JQ. She decided to chimp out and retreat back to normie conservatism. Where I might add, she's now hyperactively shilling for Israel and non-racist white conservatives. Which is, you know, whatever. You do use this. Now that's the background. Here's how I believe she could be interpreted as a coon for this behavior. Tree of Logic has openly said that she allied with the alt-right only because she wanted to defend white people from the anti-white left. Russia has spent the last few years growing its list of Western enemies, but the country's relationship with Israel has only improved. In spite of Russian support for Syria and a long history of tense adversarial relations, Israel and Russia are close geopolitical allies. So why exactly do the two countries love each other? Well, the political and social history of Russia and Israel is actually incredibly unique. Early on in Israel's formation, the Soviet Union was a major supporter of a Jewish state. Allegedly, Russian dictator Joseph Stalin expected the new country to be socialist, and the USSR was even the second country in the world to recognize Israeli sovereignty after the United States. However, this support was not long lasting. In an effort to gain control over the Middle East, Russia funded and armed countries like Syria, Iraq, Libya, Egypt and others. Meanwhile, the United States provided military and financial support to Israel, creating a de facto adversary to the Soviet Union. And yet, in spite of their political divide, the people of Israel and Russia have seen parallel social development. Due to the Soviet Union's persecution of religion, and in particular the country's state-sanctioned anti-Semitism, Israel served as a welcoming home for Jewish Russians, known as Refuseniks. In 1970, a group of Refuseniks attempted to hijack an airplane in order to escape the Soviet Union. And while they failed, it drew international attention to the fact that conditions within Russia were terrible, and those who wanted to leave weren't allowed to. Famed music producer and convicted murderer Phil Spector has died at the age of 81. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation revealed in a statement that Phil, who had been an inmate at the California health care facility in Stockton, California since 2013, had passed away from natural causes. While it is currently unknown what caused Phil's death, the CDCR noted that his official cause of death will be determined by the medical examiner in the San Joaquin County Sheriff's Office. In the same statement, the CDCR also included an updated mugshot of Phil that was taken last November. Phil, who often wore wigs before his conviction, is seen bald and smiling in the recent mugshot. Back in 2009, Phil was found guilty of second-degree murder for the death of actress Lana Clarkson. This conviction happened in a second trial after the first one was deadlocked in 2007. Phil ended up being sentenced to 19 years to life in prison and was eligible for parole hearing in 2025. Phil, who was born Harvey Philip Spector in 1939, is known for revolutionizing rock and pot music in the 1960s with his layered wall of sound production technique. During his career, Phil has produced music for legendary bands and artists such as The Beatles, The Ramones, and even Cher.

Trump's ends top officials to attend Christian's Ionist Conference Memo, a number of senior officials in the Trump administration will be in attendance at a major gathering this week of powerful lobby group Christians United for Israel, Koufai, reported Haritz. According to the paper, the conference will feature speeches by Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, as well as by Trump's National Security Advisor, John Bolton. His special envoy to the Middle East, Jason Greenblatt, and his ambassador to Israel, David Friedman. The annual summit, held in Washington, D.C., will take place today and tomorrow, attracting thousands of evangelical Christians from across the U.S. Other speakers at the event include Republican Senators Ted Cruz of Texas, Marco Rubio of Florida, Roy Blunt of Missouri and Tim Scott of South Carolina. Although Koufai describes itself as bipartisan organization, no Democratic senators are scheduled to speak. According to Haritz, the decision to send senior administration officials to the Koufai gathering is, no coincidence, since evangelicals are a key voting block for Trump and the Republicans. Around 80 percent of white evangelicals voted for Trump in 2016, helping him secure victories in several swing states. The paper stated, The consensus among U.S. political analysts is that the president will need similar or greater support among evangelicals to win a second term next year. When the Trump administration relocated the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem, Koufai founder Texas pastor John Hagee gave a speech at the opening ceremony, declaring, There has never been a more pro-Israeli president than Donald Trump. The paper added that for Trump, the support of the overwhelming majority of white evangelicals, those who voted for him in 2016 and who love his Israel policies, is crucial. According to recent reports, the president's reelection campaign will seek to mobilize even more evangelical voters. This article originally appeared on Middle East Monitor.

In a five-year period, 122 workers died, Thai workers, in the Israeli agricultural sector. I was at a Moxab the day after a worker died and asleep. He'd been working 17 hours a day, seven days a week, and he'd been given four days off per year. In all the cases that we encounter until now that a Thai worker had died in his sleep, nobody went to actually check how many hours he worked in that day, what kind of accommodation they had if he was spraying or not spraying pesticides. What concerns us greatly is whether or not these living and working conditions are contributing to the very problematic pattern of death. There are approximately 25,000 Thai workers in Israel right now, almost exclusively doing all the work in Israel's agricultural sector. Since 2011, when Israel signed a bilateral agreement with the government of Thailand, it's only been Thai workers who've been coming in. We need them for our economy. The far away we shut their field and shut their business if they don't have workers. And only foreign workers come to work in agriculture. So we have to treat them as our guests and to take care of them. When we visit these workers, you keep finding the same problems. Workers living in really squalid accommodation. Before he was stopped, they put in chemical and motor and everything he kept inside. The farmer would usually just let the workers live in the cheapest place he can find. His old packaging house, his old warehouses, his old chicken houses. It's usually in the backyard of every big villa in every village. If we go to the toilet, we go to the outside under the tree. So there was no toilet, no toilet. Thirty year old, forty year old men and women that are here to work for five years and three months is supposed to be their home. And none of the farmers and me or any Knesset member will allow their kids to sleep in these places. We conducted a survey among 500 workers. No one was getting minimum wage. Workers have to spray pesticides. Many of the workers we spoke to were clearly not given adequate protection when they did that. In the summer when it's outside, you can get up to 35, 40 degrees and then in there it gets up to 60 degrees. It's very, very hard to breathe in this situation. The workers are working incredibly long hours in incredible heat. And in some cases there's this great concern that workers may in fact be being worked to death. The employer is fully aware that the likelihood of any prosecution for unviolating workers' rights is very low. So if he wants to make a worker work for 20 hours a day, he can. When you have excellent laws in place, you have the perception that this is a very well regulated sector. But if those laws aren't properly enforced, then you move quickly to a very badly regulated sector. They come here for five years, they leave their families, they leave their kids and they deserve to be treated properly, to be treated according to the law.
